video.title: I've done programming tutorials. Now what? - Ask Preethi
video.description:
Question: "I know HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery, etc. I've followed lots of tutorials to make simple sites. But now I'm stuck. What do I do next? What can I use to actually start building something?"

My answer is in this video.

About Preethi:
Preethi Kasireddy is an engineer based in San Francisco. She's an avid learner who taught herself programming and machine learning, and is passionate about understanding things clearly and explaining them to others via blog posts.

She was previously a front-end & API engineer at Coinbase, a digital currency platform, where she helped architect and rebuild their front-end in React, Mobx and Redux. Prior to that, she was a partner at the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz and an Investment Banker at Goldman Sachs. She studied Systems Engineering at USC.

Twitter: https://twitter.com/iam_preethi

-

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.com

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.com

topLevelComment.author: michaelaaronw
topLevelComment.text: I guess this video isn't so new but I loved it! I am at the "deployed my basic app on heroku using node" stage but I feel like every example I see out there is way more complicated than my single pager. Also all my code is one file of 1000 lines and I don't really know how to modularize it. One question though...as much as I love building out my own app, I also need to get a job soon, how do you know when you're "employable"? I am also interested in blockchain, machine learning, but I'm indecisive (I also really like data visualization and geographic related things... Anyway, cheers! Thanks for the awesome videos!

topLevelComment.author: Yannick G
topLevelComment.text:
Then open a book. Tuts are shitty stuff for knowing how-to-do and really often don't help you in understanding-what-you-do ... and why-you-do-or-not.
They show parts but not even the context. You loose your time if you don't learn by books or documentation and invests time. It's not like you're gonna watch 10 minutes of bla-bla and learn the job. If you don't keep in mind what a tutorial is made for, you will eat promises all your programming life ... when you think that people will give you efficient knowledge for free you are mislead.
A lot of people think they can teach. They don't teach. They give some cooking recipes. And that stuff prevents you from learning the fundamentals and making your own learning strategy.

topLevelComment.author: Mr Zen
topLevelComment.text: You should have created a portfolio before u even moved to JavaScript and jquery, once u build your first website , u will get motivated for the second one , and you will be much more comfortable with html and css if u had build a portfolio when u learned them , now u know all these languages, it will be hard for you to put them all together for your first website. But u can do it !

topLevelComment.author: ForeverSleepy
topLevelComment.text:
Just  improve your math skills and then design methods to solve real math problems. You might not need math but if you ever decide to go into graphics programming, you'll be glad you learned math. Also, get a proper book on your language of choice and study it to the nth degree. Then actually put to practice what you've been reading, instead of copying code that you really don't know the inner workings of.

 The main problem for many is learning the actual syntax of the language but then they get stuck when actually trying to design something. This only tells me that they spent too long learning the grammar but they aren't trying to construct proper sentences and in this case, the sentences are the software.

It doesn't have to be just books. It can be any resource, as long as you aren't mindlessly copying and not really understanding what you're typing. The reason you see programmers seemingly coming up with solutions to problems and just typing out lots of code with you going: "How the hell can they do that?" It's because that's their actual code they're typing. Not someone else's. There's thousands of ways to make the same thing in programming and it's only when you start to find a balance between referencing code and actually typing and tinkering with your own, you'll find that things just come to you a lot quicker than before.

Great software developers don't memorize, they operate and construct solutions to the problem by trying to solve it themselves.

replies.author: Carver
replies.text:
She just paid someone over seas (probably one of her cousins) to do the programming.  That's how 98% of "App developers" create their apps, especially the ones that create bullshit videos like this and try to help others.

This method really never works though because you need to know how to do what you're teaching if you want to be successful.  That's why there are so many people trying to teach you to be an app developer, when none of them have even had enough success to support themselves without YouTube videos and shitty Twitter MLM crap.

topLevelComment.author: Wesley Pimentel
topLevelComment.text:
Thanks a lot for this video, I have this relationship of love and hate programming...
Database for apps, this is my question, this is my doubt! Which one is better, and cheap? NoSQL or SQL? You said you used MySQL + Node, do you recommend it?

I actually did what you said: copied the structure a Thread/Comment app and built my own TodoList app, and learned a bunch of stuff, MVC is now clearer in my mind. So, through thisI learned a little of Ionic/Typescript, I only know how to use one database, Firebase, my app is a shabby work, the CSS is not adjusting very well  to screen :/ 
I started learning Design Patterns these days, very cool indeed. Javascript is a must.

replies.author: David Shin
replies.text: Check out Knex.js if you are using Node.js in order to communicate between your backend and a database. Knex.js can talk to PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQLite3, all of which you can use for free, at least for personal projects.

topLevelComment.author: Vincenzo Pellegrini
topLevelComment.text: Nice talk as I myself going through this journey but if I could add something to your speech then it would be to take a break whenever you feel like not achieving something straightaway. If you tried your best and it still doesn't work then get your hands off the keyboard for a little while and come back later. I was very much surprised how many issues I fixed that way!

replies.author: Kerry Boomsliter
replies.text: My father said he smoked because that's how he solved problems.  He'd walk away, perhaps outside then have a smoke.   When he came back the answer was waiting for him...so he said.  I never smoked but picked up the short break habit.  Works for me.

topLevelComment.author: Arthur Brant
topLevelComment.text: That's a great testimony. I'm at this position right now. I've been learning so many great things, like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery. And now that I finally got an internship, I have to learn other things that I know are inevitable, like Python, but don't have time to put my effort in building something with things that I've already learned. I still want to build my own things, that can really help with something. Anyway, great video! Thank you! 👌

topLevelComment.author: James Canham
topLevelComment.text:
TL;DW

1. Pick a motivating project
2. Build it, but keep it simple and add complexity as you go
3. Copy code and play around with
4. Use the internet when you get stuck
5. Rewrite your programs when you learn new solid computer science concepts or design patterns
